docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton tonight assembled the patchwork proposals of his last Presidential campaign into an agenda for his final term, issuing a ''call to action'' to the nation and arguing that even within straitened budgets the Federal Government could help improve education, modernize technology and provide health care. The ideas, themes and even phrases of last year's campaign rang through his State of the Union Message tonight as Mr. Clinton strove to show how they would transcend clever electoral politics to become sound and lasting policy.

headline.main: PRESIDENT, CITING EDUCATION AS TOP PRIORITY OF 2D TERM, ASKS FOR A 'CALL TO ACTION'

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton outlines agenda for second term, State of Union speech to Congress; holds Government, despite budget constraints, can help improve education, modernize technology and provide health care; makes education top priority; urges Congress to balance budget without amending Constitution and to enact campaign finance laws; cites possibilities of high technology; calls for racial healing; Sen Trent Lott, majority leader, lauds Clinton's bid for cooperation; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Whitman administration announced new regulations for health maintenance organizations today that are aimed at giving consumers more say over their health care, including the power to appeal -- to an independent panel -- any decision to limit care. The new rules, which represent the state's first major overhaul of the regulations governing H.M.O.'s in more than two decades, would also require the H.M.O.'s to make public any financial incentives they offer doctors to withhold care. In addition, the rules prohibit the H.M.O.'s from limiting what physicians can tell patients about treatment options, including costly ones not covered by their insurance.

headline.main: New H.M.O. Rules Expand Patient Rights and Create an Arbitration Panel

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Whitman administration announces new regulations for health maintenance organizations that are aimed at giving consumers more say over their health care, including power to appeal to independent panel any decision to limit care; new rules outlined; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Whether or not the experts resolve their disagreement over when to begin regular mammography screenings (news article, Jan. 28), it's clear that these tests are still the most effective tool we have to detect breast cancer in its earliest stages. As long as this is the case, New York State will continue to take steps designed to insure access to this vital, life-saving procedure.

headline.kicker: Let Mammography Debate Be Guided by Facts

docs.abstract: Letter from New York State Senate Majority Leader Joseph L Bruno, commenting on January 28 article, says, whether or not experts resolve disagreements over regular mammography screenings, tests are still most effective tool for detecting breast cancer in earliest stages; says state will continue to take steps to insure access to vital, life-saving procedure (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. BARBARA WEBER is still reeling from the experience of a patient who told her insurance company that she had a mutated gene that could cause breast cancer. The woman had been tested for the mutation at Dr. Weber's clinic at the University of Pennsylvania, and Dr. Weber told her the results. Since some studies indicate that women with the mutated gene have a 90 percent chance of developing breast cancer, the woman wanted both of her breasts removed right away. Before she had the operation, she submitted a claim to her insurance company, Dr. Weber said, not disclosing that she had had the genetic test but reporting a strong family history of breast cancer.

headline.main: Advent of Testing for Breast Cancer Genes Leads to Fears of Disclosure and Discrimination

docs.abstract: Advent of testing for breast cancer genes prompts fears of disclosure and discrimination; many women whose tests reveal they are genetically prone to breast cancer find that their insurance companies will not pay for surgery because they consider test results as a pre-existing condition; Dr Barbara Weber of University of Pennsylvania says patients who get gene testing are refusing to enroll in studies for fear of discrimination; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even while pledging to work with President Clinton in a bipartisan spirit, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said today that he opposed Mr. Clinton's proposal to set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending. He also said there was little money available to fix the new welfare law in ways sought by the President. Mr. Lott told the National Governors' Association that he agreed with its position on Medicaid, adamantly opposing a limit on Federal spending in the program. Governors fear that such a limit would shift costs to the states, which already pay 42 percent of Medicaid costs nationwide.

headline.main: In Address to Governors, Lott Opposes Medicaid Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Last June 19, Doug Padilla left his home here in late afternoon for a five-mile run. He would have preferred to be in Atlanta, at the Olympic trials, but he had missed the qualifying time for 5,000 meters. So he had turned his attention to masters competitions, in which he could compete when he turned 40 in four months. Padilla had been an Olympian in 1984 and 1988 but had struggled for three years with mononucleosis. Now at least he was feeling healthy and was training consistently. If the Summer Games were beyond him, he would be a force on the masters circuit.

headline.main: Padilla Fights to Recover After Being Hit by a Car
headline.kicker: TRACK AND FIELD: A Top Runner Waits to Walk

docs.abstract: Article on world class runner Doug Padilla working on recovery from shattered leg after being struck by car; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The driving on the Lawrence Welk Highway had deteriorated into whiteout conditions as another blizzard scoured the North Dakota plains. But in a well-heated former tractor showroom, Susan Horner was booking vacations to Hawaii and Florida. ''People ask, 'How are you surviving it up there?' '' Mrs. Horner said of the guilt pangs of people who telephoned a reservations center in North Dakota to book sunny vacation trips with Rosenbluth International, the third largest travel company in the world.

headline.main: Telemarketing Finds a Ready Labor Market in Hard-Pressed North Dakota

docs.abstract: Telecommunications businesses are fueling economic boom in North Daktoa, with thousands of jobs added in last two years that planners say may be way to stop long-running brain drain; as state enjoys lowest unemployment rate in country of 1.9 percent, companies are moving throughout countryside searching for hidden unemployed; in past two years telecommunications companies have announced start or expansion of 40 businesses (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After months of invoking bipartisanship, President Clinton this week formally presents his legislative agenda and his budget, beginning the long struggle that will determine whether the Republican-controlled Congress and the Democratic President can really enter a season of cooperation. Mr. Clinton starts off this debate in a stronger position than in years, given new legitimacy in his re-election and the highest public approval ratings of his Presidency. Indeed, Republicans are no longer pronouncing his proposals dead on arrival, though that is in part because Mr. Clinton has moved so far in their direction since the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994.

headline.main: Clinton's Agenda and Budget Will Test Tone of Amity

docs.lead_paragraph: After 17 years together, most spent in a haze of drugs and anger, Robert and Evelyn R. are getting to know each other. The drugs were his, the anger was hers and the suffering belonged to everyone, especially the children, Chris and Melissa. Now, instead of taking drugs, he works. Instead of shouting, she talks. Together, with the help of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of seven charitable agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, they are rebuilding their family.

headline.main: After Years of Fighting, a Family Is Finding Itself

docs.abstract: Family of four discuss how they were helped by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund charitable agencies (M)
